places.name: Djinguereber Mosque
places.description: The oldest and largest of Timbuktu’s three great mud‑brick mosques, built 1327. A UNESCO World Heritage site and center of learning at the University of Timbuktu.

places.name: Sankoré Madrasah
places.description: 14th‑century mosque that developed into a madrasa, part of the University of Timbuktu. Famous for its courtyard and ancient teaching tradition.

places.name: Sidi Yahya Mosque
places.description: Constructed 1400–1440, this mosque and madrasa is part of the University of Timbuktu. Its gate was famously sealed until the end of time.

places.name: Ahmed Baba Institute
places.description: Research library preserving some 20,000 ancient manuscripts (14th–16th century). Opened in 2009, houses modern digitization and conservation facilities.

places.name: Ethnological Museum of Timbuktu
places.address: Just south of Sidi Yahya Mosque, Timbuktu, Mali
places.description: Displays local Neolithic, Tuareg, and Songhai artifacts. Includes traditional well, and offers insight into cultural history.

places.name: Musée Mansour Kore
places.address: East of Djinguereber Mosque, Timbuktu, Mali
places.description: Housed in a restored traditional mud‑brick home, exhibiting daily‑life artifacts—furniture, tools, displays of historical significance.

places.name: La Maison des Artisans
places.address: Across from Petit Marché, Timbuktu, Mali
places.description: Artisan centre showcasing traditional ironwork, leather, weaving. Visitors can watch craftsmen at work and buy silver jewelry, leather goods.

places.name: Camel Trek to Sahara Nomad Camp
places.description: Guided camel ride into the Sahara to visit a Tuareg nomad camp—experience desert life, dunes, traditional songs and meals.
